sen.j: 佐々木 道誉（ささき どうよ）／京極 道誉（きょうごく どうよ）は、鎌倉時代末期から南北朝時代 (日本)の武将。
sen.e: Doyo SASAKI/Doyo KYOGOKU was a warlord between the end of Kamakura Period and period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties.
Doyo SASAKI (also known as Doyo KYOGOKU) was a warlord between the end of Kamakura Period and the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties.
sen.cmt: Why no information as to the different names?

sen.j: 道誉は戒名で、諱は高氏（たかうじ）。
sen.e: Doyo was his posthumous Buddhist name and Takauji was his real name.
Doyo was his posthumous Buddhist name and Takauji was his real name.

sen.j: 官位は左衛門尉、検非違使、佐渡守など。

His official position was Saemon-no-jo (an official of Saemon-fu), investigative officer, Sado no kami (chief of Sado Province).

sen.j: 近江国の地頭である佐々木氏京極氏に生まれ、執権北条高時に御相供衆として仕える。
sen.e: Born in the family of Sasaki-Kyogoku which served as land steward in Omi Province, he served for the regent Takatoki HOJO as Oaitomoshu.
Born into the family of Sasaki-Kyogoku, which served as land stewards in Omi Province, he was in the service of the regent, Takatoki HOJO, as Oaitomoshu.

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇の綸旨を受け鎌倉幕府を倒すべく兵を挙げた足利尊氏に従い、武士の支持を得られなかった後醍醐天皇の建武の新政から尊氏と共に離れ、尊氏の開いた室町幕府において政所や六ヶ国の守護を兼ねた。
sen.e: Though he Followed Takauji ASHIKAGA who raised an army against the Kamakura bakufu under Emperor Go-Daigo's command, Takauji and Doyo put distance from Emperor Go-Daigo since the new political system, Kenmu Restoration was not supported by vassals, then Doyo served for Takauji who opened the Muromachi bakufu, as an administrative board or six constables.

Though he was a follower of Takauji ASHIKAGA, who had raised an army against the Kamakura bakufu under Emperor Go-Daigo's command, due to the fact that the political order Emperor Go-Daigo had attempted to create through the Kenmu Restoration did not garner the support of the samurai class, Takauji and Doyo had distanced themselves from him, and Doyo subsequently served Takauji, who founded the Muromachi bakufu, holding joint positions as an administrative official and as constable over six provinces.
sen.cmt: It is not clear why 武士 is rendered as "vassals". Samurai class? Names, position titles…

sen.cmt: Godaigoに訂正しました。余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.e: In 1296, born in the family of Sasaki-Kyogoku clan which served as land steward in Omi Province, he took over as head of the family after Munetsuna SASAKI who was his maternal grandfather in 1304.

He was born into the family of Sasaki-Kyogoku clan which served as land stewards in Omi Province, in 1296, and he took over as head of the family after Munetsuna SASAKI, who was his maternal grandfather, in 1304.

sen.j: 1314年に左衛門尉、1322年(元亨2年)には検非違使となる。

sen.j: 検非違使の役目を務めて京都に滞在していたと考えられており、後醍醐天皇の行幸に随行している。
sen.e: He was said to stay in Kyoto for his roll in statutory office and attended the Emperor Go-Daigo's visits.
He was said to have stayed in Kyoto to perform his roll as investigative officer, and to have been in attendance at the visits of Emperor Go-Daigo.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府では北条高時に御相供衆として使え、高時が出家した際には供に出家して道誉と号した。
sen.e: Serving for Takatoki HOJO as Oaitomoshu in Kamakura bakufu, he also became a priest named Doyo at the same time Takatoki became a priest.
Serving for Takatoki HOJO as Oaitomoshu in Kamakura bakufu, he also became a Buddhist priest, assuming the name Doyo, at the same time that Takatoki took the tonsure.

sen.e: Serving for Takatoki HOJO as Oaitomoshu (御相供衆) in Kamakura bakufu, he also became a Buddhist priest, assuming the name Doyo, at the same time that Takatoki took the tonsure.

sen.j: 1331年に後醍醐天皇が討幕運動を起こし、京都を脱出して笠置山 (京都府)に拠った元弘の乱では幕府が編成した鎮圧軍に従軍し、主に京都において事後処理を担当している。
sen.e: In 1331, in the event of the Genko War which Emperor Go-Daigo raised an army against the shogunate and locked himself in Kasagi-yama Mountain escaping from Kyoto, Doyo joined in the shogunate army to put down the rebellion and was mainly in charge of actions after the war in Kyoto.

In 1331, at the onset of the Genko War, which Emperor Go-Daigo had instigated by raising an army against the shogunate, removing himself from the capital (Kyoto) and setting up a base on Kasagi-yama Mountain, Doyo joined the shogunate army to put down the rebellion, and had been mainly in charge of implementing measures after the war in Kyoto had finished.

In 1331, at the onset of the Genko War, which Emperor Godaigo had instigated by raising an army against the shogunate, removing himself from the capital (Kyoto) and setting up a base on Kasagi-yama Mountain, Doyo joined the shogunate army to put down the rebellion, and had been mainly in charge of implementing measures after the war in Kyoto had finished.

sen.j: 捕らえられた後醍醐天皇は廃され、供奉する阿野廉子、千種忠顕らが隠岐島へ配流された際には道中警護などを務める。
sen.e: Captured Emperor Go-Daigo was stepped down and Renshi ANO and Tadaaki CHIGUSA who went along with the Emperor were sent to the Okino-shima Island. Doyo guarded them on the journey.
Captured Emperor Go-Daigo was forced to rennounce his claim to power, and was exiled to Okino-shima Island, with Renshi ANO and Tadaaki CHIGUSA in attendance, and Doyo guarding them on the journey.

sen.j: 後醍醐配流後も河内国の楠木正成らは反幕府活動を続けて幕府軍と戦った。
sen.e: Even after deportation of Emperor Go-Daigo, Masashige KUSUNOKI who lived in Kawachi Province fought against bakufu.

sen.j: 北条氏が下野国の足利尊氏(高氏)らを討伐に派遣する。

sen.j: 軍事的行動に参加した形跡は無いが、1333年5月9日、近江国番場で東国へ退却中の北条仲時の軍勢を阻み、蓮華寺で一族432人と共に自刃させた。
sen.e: Though there was no evidence that Doyo joined the military operation, Doyo prevented Nakatoki HOJO from retreating and escaping to Kanto area at Bamba region, Omi Province on May 9, 1333 and made Nakatoki commit suicide at Renge-ji Temple with 432 of his families and troops.

Though there is no evidence that Doyo took part in the military operation, he did block Nakatoki HOJO's retreat at Bamba, Omi Province on May 9, 1333, thereby preventing his escape to Kanto, and forced Nakatoki to commit suicide at Renge-ji Temple along with 432 of his retainers.

sen.j: その際光厳天皇や花園天皇を捕らえ、天皇から三種の神器を接収している。
sen.e: At that time, he captured Emperor Kogon and Emperor Hanazono and took over the three sacred treasures.
At that time, he captured Emperor Kogon and Emperor Hanazono, and took possesion of the three sacred treasures (the Imperial regalia).
At that time, he captured Emperor Kogon and Emperor Hanazono, and took possession of the three sacred treasures (the Imperial regalia).

sen.j: 足利尊氏、上野国の新田義貞らの活躍で鎌倉幕府は滅亡し、入京した後醍醐天皇により建武の新政が開始されると、雑訴決断所の奉行人となる。
sen.e: After Takauji ASHIKAGA and Yoshisada NITTA who lived in Kozuke Province fought well and defeated Kamakura bakufu, the Kenmu Restoration was started by Emperor Go-Daigo and Doyo was appointed as a judge of Zasshoketsudansho (court of fief).

After Takauji ASHIKAGA and Yoshisada NITTA, who lived in Kozuke Province, fought well and defeated Kamakura bakufu, the Kenmu Restoration was started by Emperor Go-Daigo, and Doyo was appointed as a judge of the Zasshoketsudansho (a type of civil court).

After Takauji ASHIKAGA and Yoshisada NITTA, who lived in Kozuke Province, fought well and defeated Kamakura bakufu, the Kenmu Restoration was started by Emperor Godaigo, and Doyo was appointed as a judge of the Zasshoketsudansho (a type of civil court).

sen.j: 尊氏が政権に参加せず、武士層の支持を集められなかった新政に対しては各地で反乱が起こった。
sen.e: As Takauji didn't join the new government, many samurais didn't support new government and revolted against the new restoration in various places.
As Takauji didn't join the new government, many members of the samurai class didn't support the new administration, and revolted against the restoration in various places.
As Takauji didn't join the new government, many members of the samurai class didn't support the new administration, and revolted against the restoration in various places.

sen.j: 1335年には、信濃において高時の遺児である北条時行らを擁立した中先代の乱が起こり、尊氏の弟の足利直義が守る鎌倉を攻めて占領した時行勢の討伐に向かう尊氏に道誉も従軍している。
sen.e: In 1335, Takatoki's son, Tokiyuki HOJO rose in revolt as Nakasendai Rebellion in Shinano Province, then attacked and occupied Kamakura where Takauji's brother Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA had protected, therefore, Doyo followed Takauji and joined an army to defeat Tokiyuki's force.

In 1335, Takatoki's son, Tokiyuki HOJO, rose in revolt in the Nakasendai Rebellion in Shinano Province, then attacked and occupied Kamakura, which had been under the protection of Takauji's brother, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA; therefore, Doyo followed Takauji, and joined his army to defeat Tokiyuki's force.

In 1335, Takatoki's son, Tokiyuki HOJO, rose in revolt in the Nakasendai Rebellion in Shinano Province, then attacked and occupied Kamakura, which had been under the protection of Takauji's brother, Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA; therefore, Doyo followed Takauji, and joined his army to defeat Tokiyuki's force.

sen.j: 時行勢を駆逐して鎌倉を奪還した尊氏は独自に恩賞の分配を行うなどの行動をはじめ、道誉も上総国や相模国の領地を与えられている。
sen.e: After eliminating Tokiyuki's force and recapturing Kamakura, Takauji distributed reward independently and Doyo received Kazusa Province and Sagami Province as feud.
After vanquishing Tokiyuki's force and recapturing Kamakura, Takauji distributed rewards independently, and Doyo received Kazusa Province and Sagami Province as feudal domains.
After vanquishing Tokiyuki's force and recapturing Kamakura, Takauji distributed rewards independently, and Doyo received Kazusa Province and Sagami Province as feudal domains.

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇は鎌倉の尊氏に対して上洛を求めるが新田義貞との対立などもありこれに従わず、遂には義貞に尊氏・直義に対する追討を命じた綸旨が発せられるが、建武政権に対して武家政権を樹立する事を躊躇する尊氏に道誉は積極的な反旗を勧めていたともされる。
sen.e: Though Emperor Go-Daigo asked Takauji to go up to Kyoto, Takauji didn't go because of confrontation with Yoshisada NITTA, then at last, the emperor ordered Yoshisada to kill Takauji and Tadayoshi. Takauji hesitated to establish samurai government against Kenmu Restoration, however, Doyo encouraged him to do it.

Though Emperor Go-Daigo requested that Takauji travel to Kyoto, Takauji was unable to make the trip due to conflagrations with Yoshisada NITTA and the like, as a result of which the emperor ordered Yoshisada to kill Takauji and Tadayoshi; though Takauji was hesitant to put an end to the Kenmu Restoration and install a government by the samurai class, Doyo actively encouraged him to do so.

Though Emperor Godaigo requested that Takauji travel to Kyoto, Takauji was unable to make the trip due to conflagrations with Yoshisada NITTA and the like, as a result of which the emperor ordered Yoshisada to kill Takauji and Tadayoshi; though Takauji was hesitant to put an end to the Kenmu Restoration and install a government by the samurai class, Doyo actively encouraged him to do so.

sen.j: 尊氏は箱根・竹下の戦いなどで新田軍を破り京都へ入るが、奥州から下った北畠顕家らに敗れた足利勢は一時的に兵庫から九州へ逃れた。
sen.e: Takauji defeated Nitta troop in the battle of Hakone and Takeshita, but he was defeated by Akiie KITABATAKE who came down from Oshu Province, then escaped to Kyushu through Hyogo temporarily.

Takauji defeated the Nitta army in fighting at battles in Hakone, Takeshita, and the like, and entered Kyoto; however, he was defeated in Kyoto by Akiie KITABATAKE, who had come down from Oshu Province, and then escaped to Kyushu via Hyogo, temporarily.

Takauji defeated the Nitta army in fighting at battles in Hakone, Takeshita, and the like, and entered Kyoto; however, he was defeated in Kyoto by Akiie KITABATAKE, who had come down from Oshu Province, and then escaped to Kyushu via Hyogo, temporarily.

sen.j: このとき道誉は近江に滞在して九州下向には従っていないともされる。
sen.e: At that time, Doyo was said to stay in Omi, not to go down to Kyushu.
At that time, Doyo is said to have stayed in Omi, choosing not to go to Kyushu.

sen.j: 九州から再び東上した足利勢は湊川の戦いで新田・楠木軍を撃破して京都へ入った。
sen.e: Ashikaga troops charged forward from Kyushu again, defeated Nitta and Kusunoki troops in the Battle of Minatogawa and came into Kyoto.

sen.j: 光明天皇が即位して北朝を成立させ武家政権（足利幕府、室町幕府）を樹立し、後醍醐らは吉野へ逃れて南朝を成立させる。
sen.e: Setting up the Northern Court, Emperor Komyo ascended, made Takauji establish samurai government (Ashikaga shogunate, Muromachi bakufu), while Emperor Go-Daigo escaped to Yoshino and set up the Southern Court.

sen.e: Setting up the Northern Court, Emperor Komyo ascended the throne, and had Takauji establish a samurai government (the Ashikaga shogunate, also referred to as the Muromachi bakufu), while Emperor Go-Daigo escaped to Yoshino and set up the Southern Court.

Setting up the Northern Court, Emperor Komyo ascended the throne, and had Takauji establish a samurai government (the Ashikaga shogunate, also referred to as the Muromachi bakufu), while Emperor Godaigo escaped to Yoshino and set up the Southern Court.

sen.j: 道誉は近江・飛騨国・出雲国・若狭国・上総国・摂津国の守護を歴任した。
sen.e: Doyo served as Shugo (constable) of six provinces such as Omi, Hida, Izumo, Wakasa, Kazusa and Settsu.
Doyo served as the Shugo (constable) of six provinces, including Omi, Hida, Izumo, Wakasa, Kazusa and Settsu.

sen.j: 1337年、勝楽寺（現滋賀県甲良町）に城を築き、以降没するまで本拠地とした。
sen.e: He built a castle in Shoraku-ji Temple (now Kora Town, Shiga Prefecture) in 1337 and used it as his base until he died.
He built a castle in the precincts of the Shoraku-ji Temple (now the town of Kora, in Shiga Prefecture) in 1337, and used it as his base until he died.

sen.e: However, even Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA who always criticized Doyo protected him and rejected Imperial order, as a result, Doyo and Hidetsuna were relegated to Kazusa Province, but soon they came back to the shogunate.
